an8.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an8.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an8.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an8.1:2.1.pli: “Mettāya, bhikkhave, cetovimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya aṭṭhānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
an8.1:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, you can expect eight benefits when the heart’s release by love has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.

an8.1:2.3.pli: Sukhaṃ supati, sukhaṃ paṭibujjhati, na pāpakaṃ supinaṃ passati, manussānaṃ piyo hoti, amanussānaṃ piyo hoti, devatā rakkhanti, nāssa aggi vā visaṃ vā satthaṃ vā kamati, uttariṃ appaṭivijjhanto brahmalokūpago hoti.
an8.1:2.3.eng: You sleep at ease. You wake happily. You don’t have bad dreams. Humans love you. Non-humans love you. Deities protect you. You can’t be harmed by fire, poison, or blade. If you don’t reach any higher, you’ll be reborn in a realm of divinity.

an8.1:2.4.pli: Mettāya, bhikkhave, cetovimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ime aṭṭhānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhāti.
an8.1:2.4.eng: You can expect these eight benefits when the heart’s release by love has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.

an8.1:4.1.eng: Loving just one creature with a hateless heart

an8.1:4.4.eng: a noble one creates abundant merit.

an8.1:5.1.eng: The royal potentates conquered this land

an8.1:5.4.eng: the sacrifices of the ‘casting of the yoke-pin’, <j>the ‘royal soma drinking’, and the ‘unimpeded’.

an8.1:6.1.eng: These are not worth a sixteenth part

an8.1:6.2.eng: of the mind developed with love,

an8.1:6.3.eng: as all the constellations of stars

an8.1:6.4.eng: aren’t worth a sixteenth part of the moon’s light.

an8.1:7.1.eng: Don’t kill or cause others to kill,

an8.1:7.2.eng: don’t conquer or encourage others to conquer,

an8.1:7.3.eng: with love for all sentient beings,

an8.1:7.4.eng: you’ll have no enmity for anyone.”

an8.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre.
an8.10:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond.

an8.10:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.10:1.2.eng: Now at that time the mendicants accused a mendicant of an offense.

an8.10:1.3.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno aññenāññaṃ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an8.10:1.3.eng: The accused mendicant dodged the issue, distracted the discussion with irrelevant points, and displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an8.10:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

an8.10:2.4.eng: This individual should be shown the door.

an8.10:2.5.eng: Why should you be vexed by an outsider?

an8.10:2.6.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
an8.10:2.6.eng: Take a case where a certain individual looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.

an8.10:2.7.eng: That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

an8.10:2.8.pli: Yato ca khvassa bhikkhū āpattiṃ passanti, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
an8.10:2.8.eng: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s

an8.10:2.9.eng: a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.

an8.10:2.10.eng: When they realize this they send him away.

an8.10:2.12.eng: So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

an8.10:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sampanne yavakaraṇe yavadūsī jāyetha yavapalāpo yavakāraṇḍavoti.
an8.10:3.1.eng: Suppose in a growing field of barley some bad barley appeared, just useless trash.

an8.10:3.2.pli: Tassa tādisaṃyeva mūlaṃ hoti, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ yavānaṃ;
an8.10:3.2.eng: Its roots, stem, and leaves would look just the same as the healthy barley.

an8.10:3.3.pli: tādisaṃyeva nāḷaṃ hoti, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ yavānaṃ;

an8.10:3.4.pli: tādisaṃyeva pattaṃ hoti, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ yavānaṃ—

an8.10:3.5.eng: That is, so long as the head doesn’t appear.

an8.10:3.6.pli: Yato ca khvassa sīsaṃ nibbattati, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
an8.10:3.6.eng: But when the head appears, they know that it’s

an8.10:3.8.pli: Tamenaṃ iti viditvā samūlaṃ uppāṭetvā bahiddhā yavakaraṇassa chaḍḍenti.
an8.10:3.8.eng: When they realize this they pull it up by the roots and throw it outside the field.

an8.10:3.10.eng: So that it doesn’t spoil the good barley.

an8.10:4.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
an8.10:4.1.eng: In the same way, take a case where a certain individual looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.

an8.10:4.2.eng: That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

an8.10:4.3.eng: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s

an8.10:4.4.eng: a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.

an8.10:4.5.eng: When they realize this they send him away.

an8.10:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahato dhaññarāsissa phuṇamānassa tattha yāni tāni dhaññāni daḷhāni sāravantāni tāni ekamantaṃ puñjaṃ hoti, yāni pana tāni dhaññāni dubbalāni palāpāni tāni vāto ekamantaṃ apavahati.
an8.10:5.1.eng: Suppose that a large heap of grain is being winnowed. The grains that are firm and solid form a heap on one side. And the grains that are flimsy and insubstantial are blown over to the other side.

an8.10:5.2.pli: Tamenaṃ sāmikā sammajjaniṃ gahetvā bhiyyoso mattāya apasammajjanti.
an8.10:5.2.eng: The owners take a broom and sweep them even further away.

an8.10:5.4.eng: So that it doesn’t spoil the good grain.

an8.10:5.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
an8.10:5.5.eng: In the same way, take a case where a certain individual looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.

an8.10:5.6.eng: That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

an8.10:5.7.pli: Yato ca khvassa bhikkhū āpattiṃ passanti, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
an8.10:5.7.eng: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s

an8.10:5.8.eng: a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.

an8.10:5.9.eng: When they realize this they send him away.

an8.10:5.11.eng: So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

an8.10:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso udapānapanāḷiyatthiko tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
an8.10:6.1.eng: Suppose a man needs an irrigation gutter for a well. He’d take a sharp axe and enter the wood,

an8.10:6.2.pli: So yaṃ yadeva rukkhaṃ kuṭhāripāsena ākoṭeyya tattha yāni tāni rukkhāni daḷhāni sāravantāni tāni kuṭhāripāsena ākoṭitāni kakkhaḷaṃ paṭinadanti;
an8.10:6.2.eng: where he’d knock various trees with the axe. The trees that were firm and solid made a cracking sound.

an8.10:6.3.pli: yāni pana tāni rukkhāni antopūtīni avassutāni kasambujātāni tāni kuṭhāripāsena ākoṭitāni daddaraṃ paṭinadanti.
an8.10:6.3.eng: But the trees that were rotten inside, decomposing and decayed, made a thud.

an8.10:6.4.pli: Tamenaṃ mūle chindati, mūle chinditvā agge chindati, agge chinditvā anto suvisodhitaṃ visodheti, anto suvisodhitaṃ visodhetvā udapānapanāḷiṃ yojeti.
an8.10:6.4.eng: He’d cut down such a tree at the root, lop off the crown, and thoroughly clear out the insides. Then he’d use it as an irrigation gutter for the well.

an8.10:6.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekaccassa puggalassa tādisaṃyeva hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ, seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhaddakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ—
an8.10:6.5.eng: In the same way, take a case where a certain individual looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.

an8.10:6.6.eng: That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offense.

an8.10:6.7.pli: Yato ca khvassa bhikkhū āpattiṃ passanti, tamenaṃ evaṃ jānanti:
an8.10:6.7.eng: But when the mendicants notice the offense, they know that he’s

an8.10:6.8.eng: a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.

an8.10:6.9.eng: When they realize this they send him away.

an8.10:6.11.eng: So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

an8.10:8.1.eng: They speak to people with a voice

an8.10:8.2.eng: so smooth, just like an ascetic.

an8.10:8.3.eng: But they act in secret, with their bad views

an8.10:8.4.eng: and their lack of regard for others.

an8.10:9.1.eng: You should recognize them for what they are:

an8.10:10.4.eng: they’re not ascetics, they just think they are.

an8.10:11.1.eng: When you’ve thrown out those of corrupt wishes,

an8.11:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā verañjāyaṃ viharati naḷerupucimandamūle.
an8.11:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in Verañjā at the root of a neem tree dedicated to Naḷeru.

an8.11:1.3.pli: Atha kho verañjo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an8.11:1.3.eng: Then the brahmin Verañja went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an8.11:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho verañjo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an8.11:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an8.11:2.2.pli: ‘na samaṇo gotamo brāhmaṇe jiṇṇe vuḍḍhe mahallake addhagate vayoanuppatte abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimantetī’ti.
an8.11:2.2.eng: the ascetic Gotama doesn’t bow to old brahmins, the elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; nor does he rise in their presence or offer them a seat.

an8.11:2.3.eng: And this is indeed the case,

an8.11:2.4.pli: Na hi bhavaṃ gotamo brāhmaṇe jiṇṇe vuḍḍhe mahallake addhagate vayoanuppatte abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimanteti.
an8.11:2.4.eng: for the worthy Gotama does not bow to old brahmins, elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; nor does he rise in their presence or offer them a seat.

an8.11:2.5.eng: This is not appropriate, worthy Gotama.”

an8.11:2.6.pli: “Nāhaṃ taṃ, brāhmaṇa, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yamahaṃ abhivādeyyaṃ vā paccuṭṭheyyaṃ vā āsanena vā nimanteyyaṃ.
an8.11:2.6.eng: “Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—for whom I should bow down or rise up or offer a seat.

an8.11:2.7.pli: Yañhi, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato abhivādeyya vā paccuṭṭheyya vā āsanena vā nimanteyya, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyā”ti.
an8.11:2.7.eng: If the Realized One bowed down or rose up or offered a seat to anyone, their head would explode!”

an8.11:3.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:3.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say

an8.11:3.4.pli: Ye te, brāhmaṇa, rūparasā saddarasā gandharasā rasarasā phoṭṭhabbarasā, te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an8.11:3.4.eng: For the Realized One has given up taste for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an8.11:3.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:3.5.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I lack taste.

an8.11:3.6.pli: ‘arasarūpo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī”ti.
an8.11:3.6.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

an8.11:4.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:4.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say

an8.11:4.4.pli: Ye te, brāhmaṇa, rūpabhogā saddabhogā gandhabhogā rasabhogā phoṭṭhabbabhogā, te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an8.11:4.4.eng: For the Realized One has given up delight in sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

an8.11:4.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:4.5.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m indelicate.

an8.11:4.6.pli: ‘nibbhogo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī”ti.
an8.11:4.6.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

an8.11:5.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama is a teacher of inaction.”

an8.11:5.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:5.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say that

an8.11:5.4.pli: Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, akiriyaṃ vadāmi kāyaduccaritassa vacīduccaritassa manoduccaritassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ akiriyaṃ vadāmi.
an8.11:5.4.eng: For I teach inaction regarding bad bodily, verbal, and mental conduct, and the many kinds of unskillful things.

an8.11:5.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:5.5.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of inaction.

an8.11:5.6.pli: ‘akiriyavādo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī”ti.
an8.11:5.6.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

an8.11:6.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama is a teacher of annihilationism.”

an8.11:6.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:6.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say that

an8.11:6.4.pli: Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, ucchedaṃ vadāmi rāgassa dosassa mohassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ucchedaṃ vadāmi.
an8.11:6.4.eng: For I teach the annihilation of greed, hate, and delusion, and the many kinds of unskillful things.

an8.11:6.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:6.5.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a teacher of annihilationism.

an8.11:6.6.pli: ‘ucchedavādo samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī”ti.
an8.11:6.6.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

an8.11:7.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:7.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say that

an8.11:7.4.pli: Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, jigucchāmi kāyaduccaritena vacīduccaritena manoduccaritena; jigucchāmi anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā.
an8.11:7.4.eng: For I’m disgusted by bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and by attainment of the many kinds of unskillful things.

an8.11:7.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:7.5.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m disgusted.

an8.11:7.6.pli: ‘jegucchī samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī”ti.
an8.11:7.6.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

an8.11:8.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:8.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say that

an8.11:8.4.pli: Ahañhi, brāhmaṇa, vinayāya dhammaṃ desemi rāgassa dosassa mohassa; anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ vinayāya dhammaṃ desemi.
an8.11:8.4.eng: For I teach the extermination of greed, hate, and delusion, and the many kinds of unskillful things.

an8.11:8.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:8.5.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m an exterminator.

an8.11:8.6.pli: ‘venayiko samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī”ti.
an8.11:8.6.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

an8.11:9.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:9.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say that

an8.11:9.4.pli: Tapanīyāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pāpake akusale dhamme vadāmi kāyaduccaritaṃ vacīduccaritaṃ manoduccaritaṃ.
an8.11:9.4.eng: For I say that bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind should be mortified.

an8.11:9.5.pli: Yassa kho, brāhmaṇa, tapanīyā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā, tamahaṃ ‘tapassī’ti vadāmi.
an8.11:9.5.eng: I say that a mortifier is someone who has given up unskillful qualities that should be mortified. They’ve cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.

an8.11:9.6.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, brāhmaṇa, tapanīyā pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an8.11:9.6.eng: The Realized One is someone who has given up unskillful qualities that should be mortified. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.

an8.11:9.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:9.7.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m a mortifier.

an8.11:9.8.pli: ‘tapassī samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesī”ti.
an8.11:9.8.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.”

an8.11:10.2.pli: “Atthi khvesa, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:10.2.eng: “There is, brahmin, a sense in which you could rightly say that

an8.11:10.4.pli: Yassa kho, brāhmaṇa, āyatiṃ gabbhaseyyā punabbhavābhinibbatti pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā, tamahaṃ ‘apagabbho’ti vadāmi.
an8.11:10.4.eng: I say that an immature person is someone who has given up future wombs and regeneration into a new state of existence. They’ve cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.

an8.11:10.5.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, brāhmaṇa, āyatiṃ gabbhaseyyā punabbhavābhinibbatti pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an8.11:10.5.eng: The Realized One has given up future wombs and regeneration into a new state of existence. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.

an8.11:10.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyo, yena maṃ pariyāyena sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
an8.11:10.6.eng: In this sense you could rightly say that I’m immature.

an8.11:10.7.pli: ‘apagabbho samaṇo gotamo’ti, no ca kho yaṃ tvaṃ sandhāya vadesi.
an8.11:10.7.eng: But that’s not what you’re talking about.

an8.11:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇa, kukkuṭiyā aṇḍāni aṭṭha vā dasa vā dvādasa vā.
an8.11:11.1.eng: Suppose, brahmin, there was a chicken with eight or ten or twelve eggs.

an8.11:11.2.pli: Tānāssu kukkuṭiyā sammā adhisayitāni sammā pariseditāni sammā paribhāvitāni.
an8.11:11.2.eng: And she properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated.

an8.11:11.3.pli: Yo nu kho tesaṃ kukkuṭacchāpakānaṃ paṭhamataraṃ pādanakhasikhāya vā mukhatuṇḍakena vā aṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā sotthinā abhinibbhijjeyya, kinti svāssa vacanīyo: ‘jeṭṭho vā kaniṭṭho vā’”ti?
an8.11:11.3.eng: Now, the chick that is first to break out of the eggshell with its claws and beak and hatch safely: should that be called the eldest or the youngest?”

an8.11:11.4.pli: “Jeṭṭho tissa, bho gotama, vacanīyo. So hi nesaṃ, bho gotama, jeṭṭho hotī”ti.
an8.11:11.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, that should be called the eldest. For it is the eldest among them.”

an8.11:12.1.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, avijjāgatāya pajāya aṇḍabhūtāya pariyonaddhāya avijjaṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā ekova loke anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho.
an8.11:12.1.eng: “In the same way, in this population lost in ignorance, swaddled in their shells, I alone have broken open the egg of ignorance and realized the supreme perfect awakening.

an8.11:12.2.eng: So, brahmin, I am the eldest and the first in the world.

an8.11:13.1.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, brāhmaṇa, vīriyaṃ ahosi asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ.
an8.11:13.1.eng: My energy was roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness was established and lucid, my body was tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind was immersed in samādhi.

an8.11:13.2.pli: So kho ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi;
an8.11:13.2.eng: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an8.11:13.3.pli: vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi;
an8.11:13.3.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an8.11:13.4.pli: pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharāmi sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedemi yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi;
an8.11:13.4.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

an8.11:13.5.pli: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
an8.11:13.5.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

an8.11:14.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ.
an8.11:14.1.eng: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.

an8.11:14.2.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.
an8.11:14.2.eng: I recollected many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remembered: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

an8.11:15.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, rattiyā paṭhame yāme paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā;
an8.11:15.1.eng: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.

an8.11:15.2.pli: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
an8.11:15.2.eng: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

an8.11:15.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, paṭhamā abhinibbhidā ahosi kukkuṭacchāpakasseva aṇḍakosamhā.
an8.11:15.3.eng: This was my first breaking out, like a chick breaking out of the eggshell.

an8.11:16.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ.
an8.11:16.1.eng: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

an8.11:16.2.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā, vacīduccaritena samannāgatā, manoduccaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṃ upavādakā, micchādiṭṭhikā, micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannāti. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā, vacīsucaritena samannāgatā, manosucaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṃ anupavādakā, sammādiṭṭhikā, sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi.
an8.11:16.2.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an8.11:17.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, rattiyā majjhime yāme dutiyā vijjā adhigatā;
an8.11:17.1.eng: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.

an8.11:17.2.pli: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
an8.11:17.2.eng: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

an8.11:17.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, dutiyā abhinibbhidā ahosi kukkuṭacchāpakasseva aṇḍakosamhā.
an8.11:17.3.eng: This was my second breaking out, like a chick breaking out of the eggshell.

an8.11:18.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ.
an8.11:18.1.eng: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

an8.11:18.2.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ;
an8.11:18.2.eng: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an8.11:18.3.pli: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ.
an8.11:18.3.eng: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

an8.11:18.4.pli: Tassa me evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha.
an8.11:18.4.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an8.11:18.5.eng: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.

an8.11:18.6.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti abbhaññāsiṃ.
an8.11:18.6.eng: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.’

an8.11:19.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, rattiyā pacchime yāme tatiyā vijjā adhigatā;
an8.11:19.1.eng: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.

an8.11:19.2.pli: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno, yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
an8.11:19.2.eng: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

an8.11:19.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, tatiyā abhinibbhidā ahosi kukkuṭacchāpakasseva aṇḍakosamhā”ti.
an8.11:19.3.eng: This was my third breaking out, like a chick breaking out of the eggshell.”

an8.11:20.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, verañjo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an8.11:20.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin Verañja said to the Buddha:

an8.11:20.2.eng: “The worthy Gotama is the eldest! The worthy Gotama is the best!

an8.11:20.3.pli: Abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama.

an8.11:20.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
an8.11:20.4.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

an8.11:20.5.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
an8.11:20.5.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

an8.11:20.6.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an8.11:20.6.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
